name: Soviet glazed cottage cheese bars
description: The most popular Soviet dairy sweet made at home

instructions.text: Mix all the ingredients (Aside from chocolate and oil) until you get a creamy paste-like consistency. Add the mix to a piping bag and make small little bar shapes on a tray. Then place them into the freezer until they are set.

While the bars are being frozen, you have plenty of time to make the glaze: melt chocolate on a bain-marie, add oil and stir with a spatula until very smooth and glossy. It should be quite hot and runny right before glazing.

When the bars are completely set, take them out of the freezer. Working with one at a time, string a cold curd bar on a skewer or a toothpick and dip in hot glaze or just cover from all sides using a tablespoon. It needs to be done quite fast.
Wrap in tinfoil and place back in the freezer to store them.

name: Lebanese Roasted stuffed onions
description: Can be made as a snack, appetizer or serve as a main.

instructions.text: Soak the rice in a bowl of cold water. Then fill another pot with boiling water, enough to cover the onions and a bit more. Cut the top and the bottom off the onions and cut down one side of the onions. Then place them in the boiling water and let them cook for 10 minutes (or just until the layers are soft and easily separate)

Drain the rice completely, then in a large mixing bowl add the rice, tomato paste, herbs, salt and pepper, coriander and ground meat. Mix well. Then once the onions have finished, open them up to make a shell and place 1 heaping tablespoon of the filling inside then wrap the onion around it to close it (but not too tightly so the rice can expand during cooking).

In a large, oven-safe saute pan over medium-high heat, swirl in the olive oil. When the pan is hot, place the onions seam-side down. Let cook for 2 minutes until the bottoms have browned slightly. Add vinegar to the pan and sprinkle the tops of the onions with sugar. Cover the pan and turn the heat to low. Cook for 20 minutes or until the meat and rice are fully cooked, rotating the onions halfway during cooking.

Mix all the ingredients (Aside from chocolate and oil) until you get a creamy paste-like consistency. Add the mix to a piping bag and make small little bar shapes on a tray. Then place them into the freezer until they are set.

While the bars are being frozen, you have plenty of time to make the glaze: melt chocolate on a bain-marie, add oil and stir with a spatula until very smooth and glossy. It should be quite hot and runny right before glazing.

When the bars are completely set, take them out of the freezer. Working with one at a time, string a cold curd bar on a skewer or a toothpick and dip in hot glaze or just cover from all sides using a tablespoon. It needs to be done quite fast.
Wrap in tinfoil and place back in the freezer to store them.
